CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: A new series of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) conjugated random terpolymers ( PBDTT-DPP-TPD ) were synthesized from electron - rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene ( BDTT ) , in conjugation with two electron - deficient units , pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione ( DPP ) and thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione ( TPD ) , of different electron - withdrawing strengths. The optical properties of these random terpolymers can be easily controlled by tuning the ratio between DPP and TPD ; an increase in TPD induced increased absorption between 400 and 650 nm and a lower highest occupied molecular orbital energy level , while higher DPP contents resulted in stronger absorption between 600 and 900 nm. The best power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 6.33% was obtained from PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 with [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester ( PC71BM ) due to the improved light absorption and thus a short - circuit current density ( J SC ) higher than 16 mA / cm^2. Interestingly , the trend observed in the PCE values differed from that of optical behavior of the PBDTT-DPP-TPD in terms of the DPP to TPD ratio , showing nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% . Density functional theory calculations showed that the small portions of strong electron - withdrawing DPP in PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 and PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 could provide trap sites , which suppress efficient charge transfer. In contrast , for PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10 and PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 , the effect of minor portions of TPD on electron density distribution was found to be minimal. In addition , the polymer packing and nanomorphology were investigated by grazing - incidence X-ray scattering and atomic force microscopy. The findings suggested that controlling the ratio of electron - deficient units in the random terpolymers is critical for optimizing their performance in polymer solar cells because it affects the polymer packing structure , the optical and electrical properties , and the electron distribution in the polymers . Low-band-gap polymers for bulk - heterojunction (BHJ)-type polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have been studied intensively with the aim of matching a greater part of the solar spectrum and thus harvesting more photon flux , to produce efficiencies greater than 7-9 % . 1-9 In most cases , low-band-gap polymers achieved by the donor - acceptor ( D-A ) approach do not show broad absorption , but instead the absorption maxima are redshifted , decreasing the number of absorbed photons in the visible region and ultimately limiting the achievable photocurrent. 10-13 One promising approach toward broadening the absorption of the solar spectrum is to develop random terpolymers based on the copolymerization of two different electron - rich units and one electron - deficient unit 14-16 or one electron - rich unit and two different electron - deficient units. 17-22 The judicious selection of two different electrondeficient or - rich groups with different electron - withdrawing or - donating strengths is critical to achieve complementary and broad visible light absorption , thus maximizing photon harvesting. However , successful examples of random terpolymers with broad light absorption and high efficiency are limited.

Let's think step by step.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PBDTT |
| DPP |
| TPD |
| PC71BM |
| PBDTT-DPP-TPD |
| PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 |
| PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 |
| PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10 |
| PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 |

Note: The material names are presented in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PBDTT |
| DPP |
| TPD |
| PC71BM |

Note: The following entities do not clearly refer to material names and were removed:

* "donor - acceptor" (this is a concept, not a material name)
* "copolymerization" (this is a process, not a material name)
* "electron - rich" and "electron - deficient" (these are descriptors, not material names)
* "broad visible light absorption" (this is a property, not a material name)
* "photon harvesting" (this is a concept, not a material name)

Paragraph: A new series of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) conjugated random terpolymers ( PBDTT-DPP-TPD ) were synthesized from electron - rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene ( BDTT ) , in conjugation with two electron - deficient units , pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione ( DPP ) and thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione ( TPD ) , of different electron - withdrawing strengths. The optical properties of these random terpolymers can be easily controlled by tuning the ratio between DPP and TPD ; an increase in TPD induced increased absorption between 400 and 650 nm and a lower highest occupied molecular orbital energy level , while higher DPP contents resulted in stronger absorption between 600 and 900 nm. The best power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 6.33% was obtained from PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 with [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester ( PC71BM ) due to the improved light absorption and thus a short - circuit current density ( J SC ) higher than 16 mA / cm^2. Interestingly , the trend observed in the PCE values differed from that of optical behavior of the PBDTT-DPP-TPD in terms of the DPP to TPD ratio , showing nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% . Density functional theory calculations showed that the small portions of strong electron - withdrawing DPP in PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 and PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 could provide trap sites , which suppress efficient charge transfer. The findings suggested that controlling the ratio of electron - deficient units in the random terpolymers is critical for optimizing their performance in polymer solar cells because it affects the polymer packing structure , the optical and electrical properties , and the electron distribution in the polymers . However , successful examples of random terpolymers with broad light absorption and high efficiency are limited.

Let's think step by step.

| Property Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| 400-650 nm | Range of increased absorption induced by increased TPD content |
| 600-900 nm | Range of stronger absorption induced by higher DPP content |
| 6.33% | Best power conversion efficiency (PCE) obtained |
| 16 mA/cm^2 | Short-circuit current density achieved by PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 |
| 2-6% | Nonlinear compositional dependence of PCE |
| 71 | Number of carbon atoms in [6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester (PC71BM) |
| 10-13 | Range of absorption maxima redshifted in low-band-gap polymers |
| 14-16 | Range of electron-deficient units in random terpolymers for broad absorption |
| 17-22 | Range of electron-rich units in random terpolymers for broad absorption |

Note: The values in the "Description" column are not necessarily numerical values, but rather a brief description of the property or characteristic mentioned in the paragraph.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Value of material property" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| --- | --- |

| 600-900 nm | Range of stronger absorption induced by higher DPP content |

Note: The entities that were removed were:

* "71" (number of carbon atoms in [6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester (PC71BM)) - This value does not clearly refer to a material property.
* "10-13" and "14-16" (ranges of absorption maxima redshifted in low-band-gap polymers and range of electron-deficient units in random terpolymers for broad absorption, respectively) - These values do not clearly refer to specific material properties, but rather to general trends or characteristics of certain types of materials.
* "17-22" (range of electron-rich units in random terpolymers for broad absorption) - This value does not clearly refer to a specific material property, but rather to a general trend or characteristic of certain types of materials.
